Dorm_Day1_Morning: ^Come on, there's a guest speaker today. Didn’t you enroll in some social science elective? This guy’s topic is actually on your syllabus.
^Oh? That kind of topic is pretty controversial. How did the school even approve his lecture?
^Don’t forget—under academic freedom, we can’t selectively protect some speakers while banning others based on their viewpoint. (He smirks, motioning you to follow him.)
^No more questions—just come already! I’ll be waiting at the auditorium.
Auditorium_Day1_Morning: ^Good evening, everyone. Thank you for joining us today. We’re honored to have a distinguished guest speaker with us……
^Uh, well… I want to start by saying that… (clears throat) …… appreciate the chance to… share my perspective on...
^You know, they say [Insert bad stereotype-laden joke here], ha…ha…ha…

^Look, if you’re offended, that’s… that’s really not my problem. People these days are just too sensitive. Can’t we have real discussions anymore? Or do I need to ask permission before expressing a thought?
^"Get off the stage!" "Enough already!" "You’re just spreading ignorance!"
^What you’re seeing right now is called Heckler’s Veto—it’s when…

^Don’t interrupt. Heckler’s Veto refers to situations where the audience silences a speaker through sheer volume and disruption rather than reasoned debate. It’s a controversial issue in free speech law.
^Oh, Poli asked me to come keep an eye on you while he stepped out for a moment.
^(inner monologue) This is getting out of control… should I step in?
^The student council will listen to you. So, what’s your call—should we de-escalate the situation or uphold the speaker’s legal right to be here?

s: ^The speaker's words are too sensitive and inappropriate. It's best to remove them to maintain order.
^Although unconventional, their views are fully protected under free speech.

g-0: ^(Before you can even voice your choice, campus security enters the scene. The situation is quickly contained. The speaker is escorted offstage before anything escalates further.)
^Gotcha. Relax—he paid the content-neutral security fee, so no matter what, we can’t let anything happen to him while he’s on campus.
^Oh, Content-neutral security fees are charges imposed on speakers regardless of their viewpoints to ensure security costs don’t become a tool for selective censorship.

Map_Day1_Afternoon: ^Now these students? They’re easy to deal with. The ones who think sheer numbers make them right, though… that’s another story.
^Norm… I swear I heard you shouting in there. You know Heckler’s Veto is—
^Look, that guy’s speech was awful—totally against public decency! No logic, just nonsense.
^But hey, at least this time I listened to Poli and protested properly outside.

s: ^Call Norm out—you saw them leading the heckling inside.
^Stay silent—you secretly wanted the speaker off the stage too.

ExposingNorm: ^You: Wait a second. You were the one who started yelling first!
^Well, this is a mess. We’ll have to sort this out in a student council meeting.
StayingSilent: ^(You say nothing. Norm smirks, nudging you playfully before slipping something into your hand—a piece of candy.)
